00307 /**
00308  * cvmx_spx#_clk_ctl
00309  *
00310  * Notes:
00311  * * SRXDLCK
00312  *   When asserted, this bit locks the Spi4 receive DLLs.  This bit also
00313  *   acts as the Spi4 receiver reset and must be asserted before the
00314  *   training sequences are used to initialize the interface.  This bit
00315  *   only applies to the receiver interface.
00316  *
00317  * * RCVTRN
00318  *   Once the SRXDLCK bit is asserted and the DLLs have locked and the
00319  *   system has been programmed, software should assert this bit in order
00320  *   to start looking for valid training sequence and synchronize the
00321  *   interface. This bit only applies to the receiver interface.
00322  *
00323  * * DRPTRN
00324  *   The Spi4 receiver can either convert training packets into NOPs or
00325  *   drop them entirely.  Dropping ticks allows the interface to deskew
00326  *   periodically if the dclk and eclk ratios are close. This bit only
00327  *   applies to the receiver interface.
00328  *
00329  * * SNDTRN
00330  *   When software sets this bit, it indicates that the Spi4 transmit
00331  *   interface has been setup and has seen the calendare status.  Once the
00332  *   transmitter begins sending training data, the receiving device is free
00333  *   to start traversing the calendar table to synch the link.
00334  *
00335  * * STATRCV
00336  *   This bit determines which status clock edge to sample the status
00337  *   channel in Spi4 mode.  Since the status channel is in the opposite
00338  *   direction to the datapath, the STATRCV actually effects the
00339  *   transmitter/TX block.
00340  *
00341  * * STATDRV
00342  *   This bit determines which status clock edge to drive the status
00343  *   channel in Spi4 mode.  Since the status channel is in the opposite
00344  *   direction to the datapath, the STATDRV actually effects the
00345  *   receiver/RX block.
00346  *
00347  * * RUNBIST
00348  *   RUNBIST will beginning BIST/BISR in all the SPX compilied memories.
00349  *   These memories are...
00350  *
00351  *       * spx.srx.spi4.dat.dpr        // FIFO Spi4 to IMX
00352  *       * spx.stx.cal.calendar        // Spi4 TX calendar table
00353  *       * spx.srx.spi4.cal.calendar   // Spi4 RX calendar table
00354  *
00355  *   RUNBIST must never be asserted when the interface is enabled.
00356  *   Furthmore, setting RUNBIST at any other time is destructive and can
00357  *   cause data and configuration corruption.  The entire interface must be
00358  *   reconfigured when this bit is set.
00359  *
00360  * * CLKDLY
00361  *   CLKDLY should be kept at its reset value during normal operation.  This
00362  *   register controls the SPI4.2 static clock positioning which normally only is
00363  *   set to the non-reset value in quarter clocking schemes.  In this mode, the
00364  *   delay window is not large enough for slow clock freq, therefore clock and
00365  *   data must be statically positioned with CSRs.  By changing the clock position
00366  *   relative to the data bits, we give the system a wider window.
00367  *
00368  * * SEETRN
00369  *   In systems in which no training data is sent to N2 or N2 cannot
00370  *   correctly sample the training data, software may pulse this bit by
00371  *   writing a '1' followed by a '0' in order to correctly set the
00372  *   receivers state.  The receive data bus should be idle at this time
00373  *   (only NOPs on the bus).  If N2 cannot see at least on training
00374  *   sequence, the data bus will not send any data to the core.  The
00375  *   interface will hang.
00376  */
00377 union cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl {
00378     uint64_t u64;
00379     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl_s {
00380 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00381     uint64_t reserved_17_63               : 47;
00382     uint64_t seetrn                       : 1;  /**< Force the Spi4 receive into seeing a traing
00383                                                          sequence */
00384     uint64_t reserved_12_15               : 4;
00385     uint64_t clkdly                       : 5;  /**< Set the spx__clkdly lines to this value to
00386                                                          control the delay on the incoming dclk
00387                                                          (spx__clkdly) */
00388     uint64_t runbist                      : 1;  /**< Write this bit to begin BIST testing in SPX */
00389     uint64_t statdrv                      : 1;  /**< Spi4 status channel drive mode
00390                                                          - 1: Drive STAT on posedge of SCLK
00391                                                          - 0: Drive STAT on negedge of SCLK */
00392     uint64_t statrcv                      : 1;  /**< Spi4 status channel sample mode
00393                                                          - 1: Sample STAT on posedge of SCLK
00394                                                          - 0: Sample STAT on negedge of SCLK */
00395     uint64_t sndtrn                       : 1;  /**< Start sending training patterns on the Spi4
00396                                                          Tx Interface */
00397     uint64_t drptrn                       : 1;  /**< Drop blocks of training packets */
00398     uint64_t rcvtrn                       : 1;  /**< Write this bit once the DLL is locked to sync
00399                                                          on the training seqeunce */
00400     uint64_t srxdlck                      : 1;  /**< Write this bit to lock the Spi4 receive DLL */
00401 #else
00402     uint64_t srxdlck                      : 1;
00403     uint64_t rcvtrn                       : 1;
00404     uint64_t drptrn                       : 1;
00405     uint64_t sndtrn                       : 1;
00406     uint64_t statrcv                      : 1;
00407     uint64_t statdrv                      : 1;
00408     uint64_t runbist                      : 1;
00409     uint64_t clkdly                       : 5;
00410     uint64_t reserved_12_15               : 4;
00411     uint64_t seetrn                       : 1;
00412     uint64_t reserved_17_63               : 47;
00413 #endif
00414     } s;
00415     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl_s            cn38xx;
00416     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl_s            cn38xxp2;
00417     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl_s            cn58xx;
00418     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl_s            cn58xxp1;
00419 };
00420 typedef union cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl cvmx_spxx_clk_ctl_t;
00421 
00422 /**
00423  * cvmx_spx#_clk_stat
00424  */
00425 union cvmx_spxx_clk_stat {
00426     uint64_t u64;
00427     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_stat_s {
00428 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00429     uint64_t reserved_11_63               : 53;
00430     uint64_t stxcal                       : 1;  /**< The transistion from Sync to Calendar on status
00431                                                          channel */
00432     uint64_t reserved_9_9                 : 1;
00433     uint64_t srxtrn                       : 1;  /**< Saw a good data training sequence */
00434     uint64_t s4clk1                       : 1;  /**< Saw '1' on Spi4 transmit status forward clk input */
00435     uint64_t s4clk0                       : 1;  /**< Saw '0' on Spi4 transmit status forward clk input */
00436     uint64_t d4clk1                       : 1;  /**< Saw '1' on Spi4 receive data forward clk input */
00437     uint64_t d4clk0                       : 1;  /**< Saw '0' on Spi4 receive data forward clk input */
00438     uint64_t reserved_0_3                 : 4;
00439 #else
00440     uint64_t reserved_0_3                 : 4;
00441     uint64_t d4clk0                       : 1;
00442     uint64_t d4clk1                       : 1;
00443     uint64_t s4clk0                       : 1;
00444     uint64_t s4clk1                       : 1;
00445     uint64_t srxtrn                       : 1;
00446     uint64_t reserved_9_9                 : 1;
00447     uint64_t stxcal                       : 1;
00448     uint64_t reserved_11_63               : 53;
00449 #endif
00450     } s;
00451     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_stat_s           cn38xx;
00452     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_stat_s           cn38xxp2;
00453     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_stat_s           cn58xx;
00454     struct cvmx_spxx_clk_stat_s           cn58xxp1;
00455 };
00456 typedef union cvmx_spxx_clk_stat cvmx_spxx_clk_stat_t;
00457 
00458 /**
00459  * cvmx_spx#_dbg_deskew_ctl
00460  *
00461  * Notes:
00462  * These bits are meant as a backdoor to control Spi4 per-bit deskew.  See
00463  * that Spec for more details.
00464  *
00465  *   The basic idea is to allow software to disable the auto-deskew widgets
00466  *   and make any adjustments by hand.  These steps should only be taken
00467  *   once the RCVTRN bit is set and before any real traffic is sent on the
00468  *   Spi4 bus.  Great care should be taken when messing with these bits as
00469  *   improper programmings can cause catestrophic or intermitent problems.
00470  *
00471  *   The params we have to test are the MUX tap selects and the XCV delay
00472  *   tap selects.
00473  *
00474  *   For the muxes, we can set each tap to a random value and then read
00475  *   back the taps.  To write...
00476  *
00477  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[BITSEL]   = bit to set
00478  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[OFFSET]   = mux tap value (2-bits)
00479  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[MUX]      = go bit
00480  *
00481  *   Notice this can all happen with a single CSR write.  To read, first
00482  *   set the bit you to look at with the SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[BITSEL], then
00483  *   simply read SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_STATE[MUXSEL]...
00484  *
00485  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[BITSEL]   = bit to set
00486  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_STATE[MUXSEL] = 2-bit value
00487  *
00488  *   For the xcv delay taps, the CSR controls increment and decrement the
00489  *   5-bit count value in the XCV.  This is a saturating counter, so it
00490  *   will not wrap when decrementing below zero or incrementing above 31.
00491  *
00492  *   To write...
00493  *
00494  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[BITSEL]   = bit to set
00495  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[OFFSET]   = tap value increment or decrement amount (5-bits)
00496  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[INC|DEC]  = go bit
00497  *
00498  *   These values are copied in SPX, so that they can be read back by
00499  *   software by a similar mechanism to the MUX selects...
00500  *
00501  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[BITSEL]   = bit to set
00502  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_STATE[OFFSET] = 5-bit value
00503  *
00504  *   In addition, there is a reset bit that sets all the state back to the
00505  *   default/starting value of 0x10.
00506  *
00507  *    SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[CLRDLY]   = 1
00508  *
00509  * SINGLE STEP TRAINING MODE (WILMA)
00510  *     Debug feature that will enable the user to single-step the debug
00511  *     logic to watch initial movement and trends by putting the training
00512  *     machine in single step mode.
00513  *
00514  * * SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP]
00515  *        This will put the training control logic into single step mode.  We
00516  *        will not deskew in this scenario and will require the TX device to
00517  *        send continuous training sequences.
00518  *
00519  *        It is required that SRX*_COM_CTL[INF_EN] be clear so that suspect
00520  *        data does not flow into the chip.
00521  *
00522  *        Deasserting SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP] will attempt to deskew as per
00523  *        the normal definition.  Single step mode is for debug only.  Special
00524  *        care must be given to correctly deskew the interface if normal
00525  *        operation is desired.
00526  *
00527  * * SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP_GO]
00528  *        Each write of '1' to SSTEP_GO will go through a single training
00529  *        iteration and will perform...
00530  *
00531  *        - DLL update, if SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[DLLDIS] is clear
00532  *        - coarse update, if SPX*_TRN4_CTL[MUX_EN] is set
00533  *        - single fine update, if SPX*_TRN4_CTL[MACRO_EN] is set and an edge
00534  *       was detected after walked +/- SPX*_TRN4_CTL[MAXDIST] taps.
00535  *
00536  *        Writes to this register have no effect if the interface is not in
00537  *        SSTEP mode (SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP]).
00538  *
00539  *        The WILMA mode will be cleared at the final state transition, so
00540  *        that software can set SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP] and
00541  *        SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP_GO] before setting SPX*_CLK_CTL[RCVTRN]
00542  *        and the machine will go through the initial iteration and stop -
00543  *        waiting for another SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[SSTEP_GO] or an interface
00544  *        enable.
00545  *
00546  * * SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[FALL8]
00547  *   Determines how many pattern matches are required during training
00548  *   operations to fallout of training and begin processing the normal data
00549  *   stream.  The default value is 10 pattern matches.  The pattern that is
00550  *   used is dependent on the SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[FALLNOP] CSR which
00551  *   determines between non-training packets (the default) and NOPs.
00552  *
00553  * * SPX*_DBG_DESKEW_CTL[FALLNOP]
00554  *   Determines the pattern that is required during training operations to
00555  *   fallout of training and begin processing the normal data stream.  The
00556  *   default value is to match against non-training data.  Setting this
00557  *   bit, changes the behavior to watch for NOPs packet instead.
00558  *
00559  *   This bit should not be changed dynamically while the link is
00560  *   operational.
00561  */
00562 union cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl {
00563     uint64_t u64;
00564     struct cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl_s {
00565 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00566     uint64_t reserved_30_63               : 34;
00567     uint64_t fallnop                      : 1;  /**< Training fallout on NOP matches instead of
00568                                                          non-training matches.
00569                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_fallout_nop) */
00570     uint64_t fall8                        : 1;  /**< Training fallout at 8 pattern matches instead of 10
00571                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_fallout_8_match) */
00572     uint64_t reserved_26_27               : 2;
00573     uint64_t sstep_go                     : 1;  /**< Single Step Training Sequence
00574                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_single_step_go) */
00575     uint64_t sstep                        : 1;  /**< Single Step Training Mode
00576                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_single_step_mode) */
00577     uint64_t reserved_22_23               : 2;
00578     uint64_t clrdly                       : 1;  /**< Resets the offset control in the XCV
00579                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dll_clr_dly) */
00580     uint64_t dec                          : 1;  /**< Decrement the offset by OFFSET for the Spi4
00581                                                          bit selected by BITSEL
00582                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dbg_trn_dec) */
00583     uint64_t inc                          : 1;  /**< Increment the offset by OFFSET for the Spi4
00584                                                          bit selected by BITSEL
00585                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dbg_trn_inc) */
00586     uint64_t mux                          : 1;  /**< Set the mux select tap for the Spi4 bit
00587                                                          selected by BITSEL
00588                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dbg_trn_mux) */
00589     uint64_t offset                       : 5;  /**< Adds or subtracts (Based on INC or DEC) the
00590                                                          offset to Spi4 bit BITSEL.
00591                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dbg_trn_offset) */
00592     uint64_t bitsel                       : 5;  /**< Select the Spi4 CTL or DAT bit
00593                                                          15-0 : Spi4 DAT[15:0]
00594                                                          16   : Spi4 CTL
00595                                                          - 31-17: Invalid
00596                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dbg_trn_bitsel) */
00597     uint64_t offdly                       : 6;  /**< Set the spx__offset lines to this value when
00598                                                          not in macro sequence
00599                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_mac_offdly) */
00600     uint64_t dllfrc                       : 1;  /**< Force the Spi4 RX DLL to update
00601                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dll_force) */
00602     uint64_t dlldis                       : 1;  /**< Disable sending the update signal to the Spi4
00603                                                          RX DLL when set
00604                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_dll_trn_en) */
00605 #else
00606     uint64_t dlldis                       : 1;
00607     uint64_t dllfrc                       : 1;
00608     uint64_t offdly                       : 6;
00609     uint64_t bitsel                       : 5;
00610     uint64_t offset                       : 5;
00611     uint64_t mux                          : 1;
00612     uint64_t inc                          : 1;
00613     uint64_t dec                          : 1;
00614     uint64_t clrdly                       : 1;
00615     uint64_t reserved_22_23               : 2;
00616     uint64_t sstep                        : 1;
00617     uint64_t sstep_go                     : 1;
00618     uint64_t reserved_26_27               : 2;
00619     uint64_t fall8                        : 1;
00620     uint64_t fallnop                      : 1;
00621     uint64_t reserved_30_63               : 34;
00622 #endif
00623     } s;
00624     struct cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl_s     cn38xx;
00625     struct cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl_s     cn38xxp2;
00626     struct cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl_s     cn58xx;
00627     struct cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl_s     cn58xxp1;
00628 };
00629 typedef union cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl cvmx_spxx_dbg_deskew_ctl_t;

00707                                                          compensation control block, which adjusts the

00710                                                          computed value. */

00723 /**
00724  * cvmx_spx#_err_ctl
00725  *
00726  * SPX_ERR_CTL - Spi error control register
00727  *
00728  *
00729  * Notes:
00730  * * DIPPAY, DIPCLS, PRTNXA
00731  * These bits control whether or not the packet's ERR bit is set when any of
00732  * the these error is detected.  If the corresponding error's bit is clear,
00733  * the packet ERR will be set.  If the error bit is set, the SPX will simply
00734  * pass through the ERR bit without modifying it in anyway - the error bit
00735  * may or may not have been set by the transmitter device.
00736  */
00737 union cvmx_spxx_err_ctl {
00738     uint64_t u64;
00739     struct cvmx_spxx_err_ctl_s {
00740 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00741     uint64_t reserved_9_63                : 55;
00742     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 - set the ERR bit on packets in which the
00743                                                          port is out-of-range */
00744     uint64_t dipcls                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 DIPERR on closing control words cause the
00745                                                          ERR bit to be set */
00746     uint64_t dippay                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 DIPERR on payload control words cause the
00747                                                          ERR bit to be set */
00748     uint64_t reserved_4_5                 : 2;
00749     uint64_t errcnt                       : 4;  /**< Number of Dip4 errors before bringing down the
00750                                                          interface */
00751 #else
00752     uint64_t errcnt                       : 4;
00753     uint64_t reserved_4_5                 : 2;
00754     uint64_t dippay                       : 1;
00755     uint64_t dipcls                       : 1;
00756     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;
00757     uint64_t reserved_9_63                : 55;
00758 #endif
00759     } s;
00760     struct cvmx_spxx_err_ctl_s            cn38xx;
00761     struct cvmx_spxx_err_ctl_s            cn38xxp2;
00762     struct cvmx_spxx_err_ctl_s            cn58xx;
00763     struct cvmx_spxx_err_ctl_s            cn58xxp1;
00764 };
00765 typedef union cvmx_spxx_err_ctl cvmx_spxx_err_ctl_t;
00766 
00767 /**
00768  * cvmx_spx#_int_dat
00769  *
00770  * SPX_INT_DAT - Interrupt Data Register
00771  *
00772  *
00773  * Notes:
00774  * Note: The SPX_INT_DAT[MUL] bit is set when multiple errors have been
00775  * detected that would set any of the data fields: PRT, RSVOP, and CALBNK.
00776  *
00777  * The following errors will cause MUL to assert for PRT conflicts.
00778  * - ABNORM
00779  * - APERR
00780  * - DPERR
00781  *
00782  * The following errors will cause MUL to assert for RSVOP conflicts.
00783  * - RSVERR
00784  *
00785  * The following errors will cause MUL to assert for CALBNK conflicts.
00786  * - CALERR
00787  *
00788  * The following errors will cause MUL to assert if multiple interrupts are
00789  * asserted.
00790  * - TPAOVR
00791  *
00792  * The MUL bit will be cleared once all outstanding errors have been
00793  * cleared by software (not just MUL errors - all errors).
00794  */
00795 union cvmx_spxx_int_dat {
00796     uint64_t u64;
00797     struct cvmx_spxx_int_dat_s {
00798 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
00799     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
00800     uint64_t mul                          : 1;  /**< Multiple errors have occured */
00801     uint64_t reserved_14_30               : 17;
00802     uint64_t calbnk                       : 2;  /**< Spi4 Calendar table parity error bank */
00803     uint64_t rsvop                        : 4;  /**< Spi4 reserved control word */
00804     uint64_t prt                          : 8;  /**< Port associated with error */
00805 #else
00806     uint64_t prt                          : 8;
00807     uint64_t rsvop                        : 4;
00808     uint64_t calbnk                       : 2;
00809     uint64_t reserved_14_30               : 17;
00810     uint64_t mul                          : 1;
00811     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
00812 #endif
00813     } s;
00814     struct cvmx_spxx_int_dat_s            cn38xx;
00815     struct cvmx_spxx_int_dat_s            cn38xxp2;
00816     struct cvmx_spxx_int_dat_s            cn58xx;
00817     struct cvmx_spxx_int_dat_s            cn58xxp1;
00818 };
00819 typedef union cvmx_spxx_int_dat cvmx_spxx_int_dat_t;
00820 
00821 /**
00822  * cvmx_spx#_int_msk
00823  *
00824  * SPX_INT_MSK - Interrupt Mask Register
00825  *
00826  */
00827 union cvmx_spxx_int_msk {
00828     uint64_t u64;

00833     uint64_t syncerr                      : 1;  /**< Consecutive Spi4 DIP4 errors have exceeded
00834                                                          SPX_ERR_CTL[ERRCNT] */
00835     uint64_t diperr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 DIP4 error */
00836     uint64_t tpaovr                       : 1;  /**< Selected port has hit TPA overflow */
00837     uint64_t rsverr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 reserved control word detected */
00838     uint64_t drwnng                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 receive FIFO drowning/overflow */
00839     uint64_t clserr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 packet closed on non-16B alignment without EOP */
00840     uint64_t spiovr                       : 1;  /**< Spi async FIFO overflow (Spi3 or Spi4) */
00841     uint64_t reserved_2_3                 : 2;
00842     uint64_t abnorm                       : 1;  /**< Abnormal packet termination (ERR bit) */
00843     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;  /**< Port out of range */
00844 #else

00846     uint64_t abnorm                       : 1;

00848     uint64_t spiovr                       : 1;
00849     uint64_t clserr                       : 1;
00850     uint64_t drwnng                       : 1;
00851     uint64_t rsverr                       : 1;
00852     uint64_t tpaovr                       : 1;
00853     uint64_t diperr                       : 1;
00854     uint64_t syncerr                      : 1;
00855     uint64_t calerr                       : 1;
00856     uint64_t reserved_12_63               : 52;
00857 #endif
00858     } s;
00859     struct cvmx_spxx_int_msk_s            cn38xx;
00860     struct cvmx_spxx_int_msk_s            cn38xxp2;
00861     struct cvmx_spxx_int_msk_s            cn58xx;
00862     struct cvmx_spxx_int_msk_s            cn58xxp1;
00863 };
00864 typedef union cvmx_spxx_int_msk cvmx_spxx_int_msk_t;
00865 
00866 /**
00867  * cvmx_spx#_int_reg
00868  *
00869  * SPX_INT_REG - Interrupt Register
00870  *
00871  *
00872  * Notes:
00873  * * PRTNXA
00874  *   This error indicates that the port on the Spi bus was not a valid port
00875  *   for the system.  Spi4 accesses occur on payload control bit-times. The
00876  *   SRX can be configured with the exact number of ports available (by
00877  *   SRX_COM_CTL[PRTS] register).  Any Spi access to anthing outside the range
00878  *   of 0 .. (SRX_COM_CTL[PRTS] - 1) is considered an error.  The offending
00879  *   port is logged in SPX_INT_DAT[PRT] if there are no pending interrupts in
00880  *   SPX_INT_REG that require SPX_INT_DAT[PRT].
00881  *
00882  *   SRX will not drop the packet with the bogus port address.  Instead, the
00883  *   port will be mapped into the supported port range.  The remapped address
00884  *   in simply...
00885  *
00886  *            Address = [ interfaceId, ADR[3:0] ]
00887  *
00888  *   If the SPX detects that a PRTNXA error has occured, the packet will
00889  *   have its ERR bit set (or'ed in with the ERR bit from the transmitter)
00890  *   if the SPX_ERR_CTL[PRTNXA] bit is clear.
00891  *
00892  *   In Spi4 mode, SPX will generate an interrupt for every 8B data burst
00893  *   associated with the invalid address.  The SPX_INT_DAT[MUL] bit will never
00894  *   be set.
00895  *
00896  * * ABNORM
00897  *   This bit simply indicates that a given packet had abnormal terminiation.
00898  *   In Spi4 mode, this means that packet completed with an EOPS[1:0] code of
00899  *   2'b01.  This error can also be thought of as the application specific
00900  *   error (as mentioned in the Spi4 spec).  The offending port is logged in
00901  *   SPX_INT_DAT[PRT] if there are no pending interrupts in SPX_INT_REG that
00902  *   require SPX_INT_DAT[PRT].
00903  *
00904  *   The ABNORM error is only raised when the ERR bit that comes from the
00905  *   Spi interface is set.  It will never assert if any internal condition
00906  *   causes the ERR bit to assert (e.g. PRTNXA or DPERR).
00907  *
00908  * * SPIOVR
00909  *   This error indicates that the FIFOs that manage the async crossing from
00910  *   the Spi clocks to the core clock domains have overflowed.  This is a
00911  *   fatal error and can cause much data/control corruption since ticks will
00912  *   be dropped and reordered.  This is purely a function of clock ratios and
00913  *   correct system ratios should make this an impossible condition.
00914  *
00915  * * CLSERR
00916  *   This is a Spi4 error that indicates that a given data transfer burst
00917  *   that did not terminate with an EOP, did not end with the 16B alignment
00918  *   as per the Spi4 spec.  The offending port cannot be logged since the
00919  *   block does not know the streamm terminated until the port switches.
00920  *   At that time, that packet has already been pushed down the pipe.
00921  *
00922  *   The CLSERR bit does not actually check the Spi4 burst - just how data
00923  *   is accumulated for the downstream logic.  Bursts that are separted by
00924  *   idles or training will still be merged into accumulated transfers and
00925  *   will not fire the CLSERR condition.  The checker is really checking
00926  *   non-8B aligned, non-EOP data ticks that are sent downstream.  These
00927  *   ticks are what will really mess up the core.
00928  *
00929  *   This is an expensive fix, so we'll probably let it ride.  We never
00930  *   claim to check Spi4 protocol anyway.
00931  *
00932  * * DRWNNG
00933  *   This error indicates that the Spi4 FIFO that services the GMX has
00934  *   overflowed.  Like the SPIOVR error condition, correct system ratios
00935  *   should make this an impossible condition.
00936  *
00937  * * RSVERR
00938  *   This Spi4 error indicates that the Spi4 receiver has seen a reserve
00939  *   control packet.  A reserve control packet is an invalid combiniation
00940  *   of bits on DAT[15:12].  Basically this is DAT[15] == 1'b0 and DAT[12]
00941  *   == 1'b1 (an SOP without a payload command).  The RSVERR indicates an
00942  *   error has occured and SPX_INT_DAT[RSVOP] holds the first reserved
00943  *   opcode and will be set if there are no pending interrupts in
00944  *   SPX_INT_REG that require SPX_INT_DAT[RSVOP].
00945  *
00946  * * TPAOVR
00947  *   This bit indicates that the TPA Watcher has flagged an event.  See the
00948  *   TPA Watcher for a more detailed discussion.
00949  *
00950  * * DIPERR
00951  *   This bit indicates that the Spi4 receiver has encountered a DIP4
00952  *   miscompare on the datapath.  A DIPERR can occur in an IDLE or a
00953  *   control word that frames a data burst.  If the DIPERR occurs on a
00954  *   framing word there are three cases.
00955  *
00956  *   1) DIPERR occurs at the end of a data burst.  The previous packet is
00957  *      marked with the ERR bit to be processed later if
00958  *      SPX_ERR_CTL[DIPCLS] is clear.
00959  *   2) DIPERR occurs on a payload word.  The subsequent packet is marked
00960  *      with the ERR bit to be processed later if SPX_ERR_CTL[DIPPAY] is
00961  *      clear.
00962  *   3) DIPERR occurs on a control word that closes on packet and is a
00963  *      payload for another packet.  In this case, both packets will have
00964  *      their ERR bit marked depending on the respective values of
00965  *      SPX_ERR_CTL[DIPCLS] and SPX_ERR_CTL[DIPPAY] as discussed above.
00966  *
00967  * * SYNCERR
00968  *   This bit indicates that the Spi4 receiver has encountered
00969  *   SPX_ERR_CTL[ERRCNT] consecutive Spi4 DIP4 errors and the interface
00970  *   should be synched.
00971  *
00972  * * CALERR
00973  *   This bit indicates that the Spi4 calendar table encountered a parity
00974  *   error.  This error bit is associated with the calendar table on the RX
00975  *   interface - the interface that receives the Spi databus.  Parity errors
00976  *   can occur during normal operation when the calendar table is constantly
00977  *   being read for the port information, or during initialization time, when
00978  *   the user has access.  Since the calendar table is split into two banks,
00979  *   SPX_INT_DAT[CALBNK] indicates which banks have taken a parity error.
00980  *   CALBNK[1] indicates the error occured in the upper bank, while CALBNK[0]
00981  *   indicates that the error occured in the lower bank.  SPX_INT_DAT[CALBNK]
00982  *   will be set if there are no pending interrupts in SPX_INT_REG that
00983  *   require SPX_INT_DAT[CALBNK].
00984  *
00985  * * SPF
00986  *   This bit indicates that a Spi fatal error has occurred.  A fatal error
00987  *   is defined as any error condition for which the corresponding
00988  *   SPX_INT_SYNC bit is set.  Therefore, conservative systems can halt the
00989  *   interface on any error condition although this is not strictly
00990  *   necessary.  Some error are much more fatal in nature than others.
00991  *
00992  *   PRTNXA, SPIOVR, CLSERR, DRWNNG, DIPERR, CALERR, and SYNCERR are examples
00993  *   of fatal error for different reasons - usually because multiple port
00994  *   streams could be effected.  ABNORM, RSVERR, and TPAOVR are conditions
00995  *   that are contained to a single packet which allows the interface to drop
00996  *   a single packet and remain up and stable.
00997  */
00998 union cvmx_spxx_int_reg {
00999     uint64_t u64;
01000     struct cvmx_spxx_int_reg_s {
01001 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
01002     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
01003     uint64_t spf                          : 1;  /**< Spi interface down */
01004     uint64_t reserved_12_30               : 19;
01005     uint64_t calerr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 Calendar table parity error */
01006     uint64_t syncerr                      : 1;  /**< Consecutive Spi4 DIP4 errors have exceeded
01007                                                          SPX_ERR_CTL[ERRCNT] */
01008     uint64_t diperr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 DIP4 error */
01009     uint64_t tpaovr                       : 1;  /**< Selected port has hit TPA overflow */
01010     uint64_t rsverr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 reserved control word detected */
01011     uint64_t drwnng                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 receive FIFO drowning/overflow */
01012     uint64_t clserr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 packet closed on non-16B alignment without EOP */
01013     uint64_t spiovr                       : 1;  /**< Spi async FIFO overflow */
01014     uint64_t reserved_2_3                 : 2;
01015     uint64_t abnorm                       : 1;  /**< Abnormal packet termination (ERR bit) */
01016     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;  /**< Port out of range */
01017 #else
01018     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;
01019     uint64_t abnorm                       : 1;
01020     uint64_t reserved_2_3                 : 2;
01021     uint64_t spiovr                       : 1;
01022     uint64_t clserr                       : 1;
01023     uint64_t drwnng                       : 1;
01024     uint64_t rsverr                       : 1;
01025     uint64_t tpaovr                       : 1;
01026     uint64_t diperr                       : 1;
01027     uint64_t syncerr                      : 1;
01028     uint64_t calerr                       : 1;
01029     uint64_t reserved_12_30               : 19;
01030     uint64_t spf                          : 1;
01031     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
01032 #endif
01033     } s;
01034     struct cvmx_spxx_int_reg_s            cn38xx;
01035     struct cvmx_spxx_int_reg_s            cn38xxp2;
01036     struct cvmx_spxx_int_reg_s            cn58xx;
01037     struct cvmx_spxx_int_reg_s            cn58xxp1;
01038 };
01039 typedef union cvmx_spxx_int_reg cvmx_spxx_int_reg_t;
01040 
01041 /**
01042  * cvmx_spx#_int_sync
01043  *
01044  * SPX_INT_SYNC - Interrupt Sync Register
01045  *
01046  *
01047  * Notes:
01048  * This mask set indicates which exception condition should cause the
01049  * SPX_INT_REG[SPF] bit to assert
01050  *
01051  * It is recommended that software set the PRTNXA, SPIOVR, CLSERR, DRWNNG,
01052  * DIPERR, CALERR, and SYNCERR errors as synchronization events.  Software is
01053  * free to synchronize the bus on other conditions, but this is the minimum
01054  * recommended set.
01055  */
01056 union cvmx_spxx_int_sync {
01057     uint64_t u64;
01058     struct cvmx_spxx_int_sync_s {
01059 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
01060     uint64_t reserved_12_63               : 52;
01061     uint64_t calerr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 Calendar table parity error */
01062     uint64_t syncerr                      : 1;  /**< Consecutive Spi4 DIP4 errors have exceeded
01063                                                          SPX_ERR_CTL[ERRCNT] */
01064     uint64_t diperr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 DIP4 error */
01065     uint64_t tpaovr                       : 1;  /**< Selected port has hit TPA overflow */
01066     uint64_t rsverr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 reserved control word detected */
01067     uint64_t drwnng                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 receive FIFO drowning/overflow */
01068     uint64_t clserr                       : 1;  /**< Spi4 packet closed on non-16B alignment without EOP */
01069     uint64_t spiovr                       : 1;  /**< Spi async FIFO overflow (Spi3 or Spi4) */
01070     uint64_t reserved_2_3                 : 2;
01071     uint64_t abnorm                       : 1;  /**< Abnormal packet termination (ERR bit) */
01072     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;  /**< Port out of range */
01073 #else
01074     uint64_t prtnxa                       : 1;
01075     uint64_t abnorm                       : 1;
01076     uint64_t reserved_2_3                 : 2;
01077     uint64_t spiovr                       : 1;
01078     uint64_t clserr                       : 1;
01079     uint64_t drwnng                       : 1;
01080     uint64_t rsverr                       : 1;
01081     uint64_t tpaovr                       : 1;
01082     uint64_t diperr                       : 1;
01083     uint64_t syncerr                      : 1;
01084     uint64_t calerr                       : 1;
01085     uint64_t reserved_12_63               : 52;
01086 #endif
01087     } s;
01088     struct cvmx_spxx_int_sync_s           cn38xx;
01089     struct cvmx_spxx_int_sync_s           cn38xxp2;
01090     struct cvmx_spxx_int_sync_s           cn58xx;
01091     struct cvmx_spxx_int_sync_s           cn58xxp1;
01092 };
01093 typedef union cvmx_spxx_int_sync cvmx_spxx_int_sync_t;
01094 
01095 /**
01096  * cvmx_spx#_tpa_acc
01097  *
01098  * SPX_TPA_ACC - TPA watcher byte accumulator
01099  *
01100  *
01101  * Notes:
01102  * This field allows the user to access the TPA watcher accumulator counter.
01103  * This register reflects the number of bytes sent to IMX once the port
01104  * specified by SPX_TPA_SEL[PRTSEL] has lost its TPA.  The SPX_INT_REG[TPAOVR]
01105  * bit is asserted when CNT >= SPX_TPA_MAX[MAX].  The CNT will continue to
01106  * increment until the TPA for the port is asserted.  At that point the CNT
01107  * value is frozen until software clears the interrupt bit.
01108  */
01109 union cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc {
01110     uint64_t u64;
01111     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc_s {
01112 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
01113     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
01114     uint64_t cnt                          : 32; /**< TPA watcher accumulate count */
01115 #else
01116     uint64_t cnt                          : 32;
01117     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
01118 #endif
01119     } s;
01120     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc_s            cn38xx;
01121     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc_s            cn38xxp2;
01122     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc_s            cn58xx;
01123     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc_s            cn58xxp1;
01124 };
01125 typedef union cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc cvmx_spxx_tpa_acc_t;
01126 
01127 /**
01128  * cvmx_spx#_tpa_max
01129  *
01130  * SPX_TPA_MAX - TPA watcher assertion threshold
01131  *
01132  *
01133  * Notes:
01134  * The TPA watcher has the ability to notify the system with an interrupt when
01135  * too much data has been received on loss of TPA.  The user sets the
01136  * SPX_TPA_MAX[MAX] register and when the watcher has accumulated that many
01137  * ticks, then the interrupt is conditionally raised (based on interrupt mask
01138  * bits).  This feature will be disabled if the programmed count is zero.
01139  */
01140 union cvmx_spxx_tpa_max {
01141     uint64_t u64;
01142     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_max_s {
01143 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
01144     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
01145     uint64_t max                          : 32; /**< TPA watcher TPA threshold */
01146 #else
01147     uint64_t max                          : 32;
01148     uint64_t reserved_32_63               : 32;
01149 #endif
01150     } s;
01151     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_max_s            cn38xx;
01152     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_max_s            cn38xxp2;
01153     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_max_s            cn58xx;
01154     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_max_s            cn58xxp1;
01155 };
01156 typedef union cvmx_spxx_tpa_max cvmx_spxx_tpa_max_t;
01157 
01158 /**
01159  * cvmx_spx#_tpa_sel
01160  *
01161  * SPX_TPA_SEL - TPA watcher port selector
01162  *
01163  *
01164  * Notes:
01165  * The TPA Watcher is primarily a debug vehicle used to help initial bringup
01166  * of a system.  The TPA watcher counts bytes that roll in from the Spi
01167  * interface.  The user programs the Spi port to watch using
01168  * SPX_TPA_SEL[PRTSEL].  Once the TPA is deasserted for that port, the watcher
01169  * begins to count the data ticks that have been delivered to the inbound
01170  * datapath (and eventually to the IOB).  The result is that we can derive
01171  * turn-around times of the other device by watching how much data was sent
01172  * after a loss of TPA through the SPX_TPA_ACC[CNT] register.  An optional
01173  * interrupt may be raised as well.  See SPX_TPA_MAX for further information.
01174  *
01175  * TPA's can be deasserted for a number of reasons...
01176  *
01177  * 1) IPD indicates backpressure
01178  * 2) The GMX inbound FIFO is filling up and should BP
01179  * 3) User has out an override on the TPA wires
01180  */
01181 union cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel {
01182     uint64_t u64;
01183     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel_s {
01184 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
01185     uint64_t reserved_4_63                : 60;
01186     uint64_t prtsel                       : 4;  /**< TPA watcher port select */
01187 #else
01188     uint64_t prtsel                       : 4;
01189     uint64_t reserved_4_63                : 60;
01190 #endif
01191     } s;
01192     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel_s            cn38xx;
01193     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel_s            cn38xxp2;
01194     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel_s            cn58xx;
01195     struct cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel_s            cn58xxp1;
01196 };
01197 typedef union cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel cvmx_spxx_tpa_sel_t;
01198 
01199 /**
01200  * cvmx_spx#_trn4_ctl
01201  *
01202  * Notes:
01203  * These bits are controls for the Spi4 RX bit deskew logic.  See that Spec
01204  * for further details.
01205  *
01206  * * BOOT_BIT
01207  *   On the initial training synchronization sequence, the hardware has the
01208  *   BOOT_BIT set which means that it will continueously perform macro
01209  *   operations.  Once the BOOT_BIT is cleared, the macro machine will finish
01210  *   the macro operation is working on and then return to the idle state.
01211  *   Subsequent training sequences will only go through a single macro
01212  *   operation in order to do slight deskews.
01213  *
01214  * * JITTER
01215  *   Minimum value is 1.  This parameter must be set for Spi4 mode using
01216  *   auto-bit deskew.  Regardless of the original intent, this field must be
01217  *   set non-zero for deskew to function correctly.
01218  *
01219  *   The thought is the JITTER range is no longer required since the macro
01220  *   machine was enhanced to understand about edge direction.  Originally
01221  *   these bits were intended to compensate for clock jitter.
01222  *
01223  *   dly:    this is the intrinsic delay of each delay element
01224  *              tap currently, it is 70ps-110ps.
01225  *   jitter: amount of jitter we expect in the system (~200ps)
01226  *   j:      number of taps to account for jitter
01227  *
01228  *   j = ((jitter / dly) + 1)
01229  *
01230  * * TRNTEST
01231  *   This mode is used to test systems to make sure that the bit deskew
01232  *   parameters have been correctly setup.  After configuration, software can
01233  *   set the TRNTEST mode bit.  This should be done before SRX_COM_CTL[ST_EN]
01234  *   is set such that we can be sure that the TX device is simply sending
01235  *   continuous training patterns.
01236  *
01237  *   The test mode samples every incoming bit-time and makes sure that it is
01238  *   either a training control or a training data packet.  If any other data
01239  *   is observed, then SPX_DBG_DESKEW_STATE[TESTRES] will assert signaling a
01240  *   test failure.
01241  *
01242  *   Software must clear TRNTEST before training is terminated.
01243  *
01244  * * Example Spi4 RX init flow...
01245  *
01246  * 1) set the CLKDLY lines (SPXX_CLK_CTL[CLKDLY])
01247  *    - these bits must be set before the DLL can successfully lock
01248  *
01249  * 2) set the SRXDLCK (SPXX_CLK_CTL[SRXDLCK])
01250  *    - this is the DLL lock bit which also acts as a block reset
01251  *
01252  * 3) wait for the DLLs lock
01253  *
01254  * 4) set any desired fields in SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL
01255  *    - This register has only one field that most users will care about.
01256  *      When set, DLLDIS will disable sending update pulses to the Spi4 RX
01257  *      DLLs.  This pulse allows the DLL to adjust to clock variations over
01258  *      time.  In general, it is desired behavior.
01259  *
01260  * 5) set fields in SPXX_TRN4_CTL
01261  *    - These fields deal with the MUX training sequence
01262  *      * MUX_EN
01263  *        This is the enable bit for the mux select.  The MUX select will
01264  *        run in the training sequence between the DLL and the Macro
01265  *        sequence when enabled.  Once the MUX selects are selected, the
01266  *        entire macro sequence must be rerun.  The expectation is that
01267  *        this is only run at boot time and this is bit cleared at/around
01268  *        step \#8.
01269  *    - These fields deal with the Macro training sequence
01270  *      * MACRO_EN
01271  *        This is the enable bit for the macro sequence.  Macro sequences
01272  *        will run after the DLL and MUX training sequences.  Each macro
01273  *        sequence can move the offset by one value.
01274  *      * MAXDIST
01275  *        This is how far we will search for an edge.  Example...
01276  *
01277  *           dly:    this is the intrinsic delay of each delay element
01278  *                   tap currently, it is 70ps-110ps.
01279  *           U:      bit time period in time units.
01280  *
01281  *           MAXDIST = MIN(16, ((bit_time / 2) / dly)
01282  *
01283  *           Each MAXDIST iteration consists of an edge detect in the early
01284  *           and late (+/-) directions in an attempt to center the data.  This
01285  *           requires two training transistions, the control/data and
01286  *           data/control transistions which comprise a training sequence.
01287  *           Therefore, the number of training sequences required for a single
01288  *           macro operation is simply MAXDIST.
01289  *
01290  * 6) set the RCVTRN go bit (SPXX_CLK_CTL[RCVTRN])
01291  *    - this bit synchs on the first valid complete training cycle and
01292  *      starts to process the training packets
01293  *
01294  * 6b) This is where software could manually set the controls as opposed to
01295  *     letting the hardware do it.  See the SPXX_DBG_DESKEW_CTL register
01296  *        description for more detail.
01297  *
01298  * 7) the TX device must continue to send training packets for the initial
01299  *    time period.
01300  *    - this can be determined by...
01301  *
01302  *      DLL: one training sequence for the DLL adjustment (regardless of enable/disable)
01303  *      MUX: one training sequence for the Flop MUX taps (regardless of enable/disable)
01304  *      INIT_SEQUENCES: max number of taps that we must move
01305  *
01306  *         INIT_SEQUENCES = MIN(16, ((bit_time / 2) / dly))
01307  *
01308  *         INIT_TRN = DLL + MUX + ROUNDUP((INIT_SEQUENCES * (MAXDIST + 2)))
01309  *
01310  *
01311  *    - software can either wait a fixed amount of time based on the clock
01312  *      frequencies or poll the SPXX_CLK_STAT[SRXTRN] register.  Each
01313  *      assertion of SRXTRN means that at least one training sequence has
01314  *      been received.  Software can poll, clear, and repeat on this bit to
01315  *      eventually count all required transistions.
01316  *
01317  *      int cnt = 0;
01318  *      while (cnt < INIT_TRN) [
01319  *             if (SPXX_CLK_STAT[SRXTRN]) [
01320  *                cnt++;
01321  *                SPXX_CLK_STAT[SRXTRN] = 0;
01322  *             ]
01323  *      ]
01324  *
01325  *   - subsequent training sequences will normally move the taps only
01326  *     one position, so the ALPHA equation becomes...
01327  *
01328  *     MAC   = (MAXDIST == 0) ? 1 : ROUNDUP((1 * (MAXDIST + 2))) + 1
01329  *
01330  *        ALPHA = DLL + MUX + MAC
01331  *
01332  *     ergo, MAXDIST simplifies to...
01333  *
01334  *        ALPHA = (MAXDIST == 0) ? 3 : MAXDIST + 5
01335  *
01336  *        DLL and MUX and MAC will always require at least a training sequence
01337  *        each - even if disabled.  If the macro sequence is enabled, an
01338  *        additional training sequenece at the end is necessary.  The extra
01339  *        sequence allows for all training state to be cleared before resuming
01340  *        normal operation.
01341  *
01342  * 8) after the recevier gets enough training sequences in order to achieve
01343  *    deskew lock, set SPXX_TRN4_CTL[CLR_BOOT]
01344  *    - this disables the continuous macro sequences and puts into into one
01345  *      macro sequnence per training operation
01346  *    - optionally, the machine can choose to fall out of training if
01347  *      enough NOPs follow the training operation (require at least 32 NOPs
01348  *      to follow the training sequence).
01349  *
01350  *    There must be at least MAXDIST + 3 training sequences after the
01351  *    SPXX_TRN4_CTL[CLR_BOOT] is set or sufficient NOPs from the TX device.
01352  *
01353  * 9) the TX device continues to send training sequences until the RX
01354  *    device sends a calendar transistion.  This is controlled by
01355  *    SRXX_COM_CTL[ST_EN].  Other restrictions require other Spi parameters
01356  *    (e.g. the calendar table) to be setup before this bit can be enabled.
01357  *    Once the entire interface is properly programmed, software writes
01358  *    SRXX_COM_CTL[INF_EN].  At this point, the Spi4 packets will begin to
01359  *    be sent into the N2K core and processed by the chip.
01360  */
01361 union cvmx_spxx_trn4_ctl {
01362     uint64_t u64;
01363     struct cvmx_spxx_trn4_ctl_s {
01364 #ifdef __BIG_ENDIAN_BITFIELD
01365     uint64_t reserved_13_63               : 51;
01366     uint64_t trntest                      : 1;  /**< Training Test Mode
01367                                                          This bit is only for initial bringup
01368                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_trn_test_mode) */
01369     uint64_t jitter                       : 3;  /**< Accounts for jitter when the macro sequence is
01370                                                          locking.  The value is how many consecutive
01371                                                          transititions before declaring en edge.  Minimum
01372                                                          value is 1.  This parameter must be set for Spi4
01373                                                          mode using auto-bit deskew.
01374                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_mac_jitter) */
01375     uint64_t clr_boot                     : 1;  /**< Clear the macro boot sequence mode bit
01376                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_mac_clr_boot) */
01377     uint64_t set_boot                     : 1;  /**< Enable the macro boot sequence mode bit
01378                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_mac_set_boot) */
01379     uint64_t maxdist                      : 5;  /**< This field defines how far from center the
01380                                                          deskew logic will search in a single macro
01381                                                           sequence (spx_csr__spi4_mac_iters) */
01382     uint64_t macro_en                     : 1;  /**< Allow the macro sequence to center the sample
01383                                                          point in the data window through hardware
01384                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_mac_trn_en) */
01385     uint64_t mux_en                       : 1;  /**< Enable the hardware machine that selects the
01386                                                          proper coarse FLOP selects
01387                                                          (spx_csr__spi4_mux_trn_en) */
01388 #else
01389     uint64_t mux_en                       : 1;
01390     uint64_t macro_en                     : 1;
01391     uint64_t maxdist                      : 5;
01392     uint64_t set_boot                     : 1;
01393     uint64_t clr_boot                     : 1;
01394     uint64_t jitter                       : 3;
01395     uint64_t trntest                      : 1;
01396     uint64_t reserved_13_63               : 51;
01397 #endif
01398     } s;
01399     struct cvmx_spxx_trn4_ctl_s           cn38xx;
01400     struct cvmx_spxx_trn4_ctl_s           cn38xxp2;
01401     struct cvmx_spxx_trn4_ctl_s           cn58xx;
01402     struct cvmx_spxx_trn4_ctl_s           cn58xxp1;
01403 };
